posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I look at a build concept with a class combo that seems to be new. I want it to become a strength based dual wielding stealth build with HIPS and Dev crit if possible.
I look to combine the Ranger, Weaponmaster and Shadowdancer classes. There are no such builds here, and there are only 3 builds with that class combo in the old forums. Two of them are dex based. The third one, another good build by Cinnabar Dinn, is strength based, but has a too strong Ranger focus for my use.
Weaponmaster is feat demanding and for that reason often combined with Fighter. You already want WF with every build, and Dodge/Mobility opens up SD. Expertise is fine sometimes, so the only less useful feats are Spring attack and WWA.
Ranger gives a good class skill selection with early access to SD and gets the Dual wield feats for free without having to take dex 15.
I could have made a strength based dual wielding stealth build with Ranger and SD alone and gotten a character with wis 14 and full Ranger spellbook and a dual wield AB of 41 or 42.
So why pay the price for WM? I can get a dual wield AB of 47 or 48 (49 or 50 with a single weapon) I also get a better threat range and have a very high AB to confirm the threats.
My only concern is if I can live with the feat starvation, especially so if I try to reach for Dev crit.
Ranger Dual wield needs fighting in light armor. How well does that fit a strength build? And will I need to take Armor proficiency heavy?
With a dexterity of 14, the best AC you can get from medium armor is from Breast plate/Chain mail with 5 + 2 = 7. Once you can self buff with Cat's, a dexterity of 18 will give 4 + 4 = 8 in Chain shirt/Scale mail, or 3 + 4 = 7 in Studded/ Hide. Not quite as good as 8 + 1 = 9 from full plate. If you have access to dexterity boosting items, dex 22 gives AC 8 in leather and capped dex 26 gives AC 9 in padded armor.
So improving dex becomes important if you want to have a competing AC and dual wield in light armor. If you need better AC than that, you can single wield and grab a shield, activate expertise, or HIPS away.
Any thoughts?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Mick,

I think I'm going to have to crap on the idea of a potential Dev Crit build - sorry. Assuming you go human for the extra feat, you're still only going to have 8 pre-epic feats, and WF, Dodge, Mobility, Expertise and the Spring and WW Attacks, make 6. That gives no room for all of PA, Cleave, GCleave and Imp Crit, unless, of course, you're happy taking a couple of them in epic levels. And even then you'd have no room for KD or Blind Fight, let alone heavy armour (the long-term merits of which I'm not sure about in any case).

An interesting stat spread that I recall is Valerfor's Dodji Domotai (apologies, links still don't seem to be working for me atm). I have played the build and enjoyed doing so. Admittedly, it's an elf Fighter16/ Rogue17/ WM7 and was apparently made with a particular purpose in mind, and has ED, but the stats are fairly unique: Str 16(26), Dex 18(25), Con 10, Wis 8, Int 14, Cha 8. Don't know if that helps or not

At least losing Dev Crit opens other avenues, maybe? I'll keep thinking...

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor

This is funny you know,
The other day I was contemplating a build with SD because Stag was on a search for a kind of unique RDD build and I thought to myself "hey what about a hinder RDD?"
From what I remember this was actually a suggestion by someone in one of my builds, in the past.
So I searched for it in the old ECB and found nothing of the sort I wanted to make (all dex-builds with very low AB etc) while I wanted a strength-based one that uses SD only for the HiPS & Evasion...

And then I deleted the file because I thought, the whole darn thing is silly in the first place. I mean he had no sneaks or CS, so what's the deal with hiding? Who would play such a thing?!
And now I see the SD again!

Anyway, let's be serious for a moment here, why do you have to take Dev Crit in the first place with this build again Mick?
You could make it, yes, but at what cost?
You want to make this one of the old "achievement builds" of the past or something that actually works & plays well?
If you want to have Dev Crit anyway, then the solution is to take as many Weapon-Master levels as possible & ditch the extra SD levels, something like Ranger 15/ SD 3/ Weapon-Master 22 or similar.
But there is another way too, I am kinda fond of Cin's "Baneblade", but to perfect it I would actually take even more Ranger levels, I think Ranger 30/ SD 3/ Weapon-Master 7 would work like a charm.
Think about it, full Ranger spells & Animal Companion, HiPS, Bane of Enemies, 30-32 Strength, Dual-Kukris, Weapon-Master Crits, yummy...

Anyway, this is getting long, so farewell for now ;)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Don't know if it would be worth it to you, but you could get your Str/AB up by 2. However, it comes at a price. If you take EWF as the WM13 bonus feat, EP at WM16 and AS at WM19, you could take Great Strength 1 at level 21. You'd also have to drop your starting Con by 2 and Int or Dex by 1 (or even Wis - I think you only need a starter of 11 for Ranger, but I might be wrong). So is 1AB worth 60 hps, either 1AC or 40 skill points or Ranger spells, and delaying EWF by 5 levels, EP by 10 and AS by 4? It wouldn't be for me, but I'm just saying that you could.

The lack of Blind Fight and Knockdown does still worry me, though. This fellow seems pretty much a one-trick pony, I'm afraid, and while the Dev Crit DC isn't at all bad, it's not stellar, and it comes fairly late in the build (and you play on hardcore as well, which ain't going help, is it?). I just wonder whether the same feat starvation that afflicted my thoughts about Bard/ WM/ RDD is similarly applicable here.

Don't get me wrong, this is probably as optimized as it's going to get, I just wouldn't fancy trying it myself.

Now, the non-Dev Crit version might be a different story...

Sorry to sound so downbeat

EDIT: Oh, and just to be selfish, shortswords are poo - go for hatchets! And they fit with Ranger.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: As a genuine question about those ESkF feats, if you've got HiPS, do higher Hide and MS skills make much difference?
HIPS let you hide in plain sight, as opposed to getting out of the line of sight before you can hide. You still have to use your hide skill to hide successfully (avoid being spotted), and your MS skill to move around undetected (among listening foes).

posts.author: Thorsson
posts.content: But the Hide/MS checks are once a round (twice a round with Elf), so can you HiPS and attack before the 'Spot' check triggers?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Thorsson wrote: But the Hide/MS checks are once a round (twice a round with Elf), so can you HiPS and attack before the 'Spot' check triggers?
Good question Thorsson!
I have no idea how this is programmed, but I experience that if you HIPS, it cancels remaining attacks in that round. What fires first in the round, a spot check or the first flurry of attacks, I don't know.
If you hide and are detected, you can reverse that by going out of stealth and enter stealth (HIPS) again immediately. If you can do that more often than the spot checks, it raises the question if you can avoid or at least escape detection by spamming HIPS even if your hide skill is very low.
